name: Can I store multiple image vectors for a point and use an average vector for search?
messages:
Is it possible to store multiple vectors for one point, and when I search using another vector, it doesn't just compare two individual vectors, but creates some kid of average from the multiple vectors stored  at that point? Similar to how the recommendation API works, but applied in the database.

I'm working on an image-based product recommendation system. Each product has multiple images, and using all of them might improve the search results. I've seen the recommendation api where you can provide multiple positive and negative examples during the search what is great, and I've also read that we can store multiple vectors and search them by selecting one. My question is: can I store multiple image vectors for one pint (product) and, when searching, have the system create an average of those vectors to improve the search accuracy like as positive examples?

name: Finding ways to improve search speed
messages:
Hi Qdrant team!

I'm recently trying to see if the search speed for some of our collections can be further improved. Currently the collection has P99 search latency ~90ms and P50 ~25ms, the qdrant cluster version is on v1.11.5, and we're calling search API via golang client version v1.11.1. The information of a typical search request is:

```
Limit:             640
SearchFilter:      must:{field:{key:"timestamp"  range:{gte:1.727808543508965e+15}}}  must:{field:{key:"topic_id"  match:{integers:{integers:7249  integers:4202  integers:5319  integers:414366  integers:179097  integers:948  integers:15617  integers:2594  integers:78928  integers:76221  integers:65314  integers:1958  integers:2307  integers:4600  integers:40427  integers:786  integers:1797  integers:2224055  integers:1996  integers:2128  integers:9578  integers:918  integers:1672953  integers:788  integers:980  integers:376915  integers:7173  integers:87257  integers:19726  integers:1759927}}}}
IncludeVectors:    false
IncludePayload:    true
SearchExact:       false
HnswEf:            200
ScoreThreshold:    nil
UseIndexedOnly:    true
WithPayloadFields: [timestamp parent_id topic_id]
```

I'll provide some more details in the comment.

name: Need Help Storing and Retrieving Q&A Data with SQL Table Integration for LLM Processing
messages:
I am working on a project where I need to store Q&A data in CSV format, including questions and answers, along with SQL table definitions. The goal is to perform a similarity search on the stored Q&A when a user asks a question, then reference the relevant SQL table definitions to fetch data and feed it into my LLMs.

Could someone assist me in finding the best approach to store this data and retrieve it in an optimized and efficient manner?

name: Use case and Limitations of Various Search Techniques - Discovery, Nearest, Context, Recommendation
messages:
I have read about various searching techniques supported by qdrant, however I am specifically looking for use cases for each of the search techniques mentioned below, when to use particular technique, what are its limitations 
1) Discovery 
2) Nearest 
3) Context 
4) Recommendation

name: Slow Search Speed
What can impoove HNSW re-index performace?
Will replication help me support more requests per second?
messages:
Hi!
I have a cluster with two nodes currently (might grow with time). The collection I am serving is in itself not very large (<100k vectors) but I get very bursty number of requests depending on the number of agents running and querying the collection. What is the preferred setup for supporting a large number of requests? Should I have more shards on many nodes or the same shards replicated to several nodes? How does the load balancing work and how should I think about this to get optimal performance?

name: Mass Deletion
messages: Hi, is it safe to delete tens of millions of vectors from a collection in a single request, or would it be better to batch these requests  (into 1000 deletions per request, for example)? By "safe", I mean will it cause the vector db to crash, hang, slow down, etc?

name: Distances when using multi vectors collections
messages:
Hello, started playing with multi vector collection recently and noticed that in some cases cosine distance was > 1 even tho all my embeddings were being normalised.

I suppose it comes from max_sim function that is used to sort between all the vectors of different points but I am not sure I got how it works in some use cases.
If I have a score of 3 does it mean that I had a cosine distance = 1 for 3 different vectors of the two points ? 
Also how does it work if I have one point with one vector with cosine = 1 but an other one with two points with cosine = 0.9 and 0.9 ? Would it return the first one as the best match or the second one ?

Thanks again for the great work

name: Principal Index issues
messages:
Hi Folks, 
I am trying to create Principal Index as specified in the https://qdrant.tech/documentation/concepts/indexing/?q=delete_payload_index
client.create_payload_index(
    collection_name="{collection_name}",
    field_name="timestamp",
    field_schema=models.KeywordIndexParams(
        type="integer",
        is_principal=True,
    ),
)
But it gave error that no additional argument is_principal allowed. SInce by field is an integer I changes it to 
    client.create_payload_index(
        collection_name = 'collectionName',
        field_name = "deptID",
        field_schema = models.IntegerIndexParams(type="integer", is_principal=True, lookup=True, range=False)
    )
Had to add lookup and range to avoid exception, selected lookup as true as I needed exact match on the field.
This ran without error. It is fine or am I missing something?

name: Issue with Point ID not being set when I specify it in my Document
messages:
When I use langchain_qdrant QdrantVectorStore and langchain_core.documents Document and try to set the id in my Document with my own UUID and then build my collection with those Documents, Qdrant assigns its own Point ID instead of using my specified UUID. 

I'm not sure what I'm doing wrong, as I can use Postman to properly specify my Point IDs using the REST API, but it's not working with the python libs. I've included my code snippets below:

                permid = result.get('internal_perm_id')
                title = result.get('internal_title', 'No Title')
                abstract = result.get('abstract_body', 'No Abstract')
                journal = result.get('journal_journal_name', 'No Journal')
                uuid = string_to_uuid(permid)
                
                doc = Document(
                    id=uuid,
                    page_content=abstract,
                    metadata={
                        'uuid': uuid,
                        'internal_perm_id': permid,
                        'internal_title': title,
                        'journal_journal_name': journal
                    }
                )
                documents.append(doc)

def create_vectorstore(documents, batch_size=5000):
    # Create embeddings using OpenAI's smallest model
    embeddings = OpenAIEmbeddings(model="text-embedding-3-small", 
                                      dimensions=512)

    # Function to process documents in batches
    def start_batch(documents):
        return QdrantVectorStore.from_documents(
            documents=documents, 
            embedding=embeddings,
            collection_name="recommendations_vector",
            url="<url>",
            port=6333,
            api_key=os.getenv("QDRANT_API_KEY")
        )

    # Function to process documents in batches
    def process_batch(vectorstore, documents):
        vectorstore.add_documents(
            documents=documents 
        )

name: Output returned differ from official document
messages:
Hi, sorry to bother if it is my misunderstanding. 
By following the [official quickstart document](https://qdrant.tech/documentation/quickstart/), i found the output i get from `client.query_points` differs from the output given, as shown below. 

**Executed code**:
```
search_result = client.query_points(
    collection_name="test_collection", query=[0.2, 0.1, 0.9, 0.7], limit=3
).points

print(search_result)
```
**Official response**;
```
[
  {
    "id": 4,
    "version": 0,
    "score": 1.362,
    "payload": null,
    "vector": null
  },
  {
    "id": 1,
    "version": 0,
    "score": 1.273,
    "payload": null,
    "vector": null
  },
  {
    "id": 3,
    "version": 0,
    "score": 1.208,
    "payload": null,
    "vector": null
  }
]
```
**My output**:
```
[ScoredPoint(id=4, version=0, score=1.362, payload={'city': 'New York'}, vector=None, shard_key=None, order_value=None), ScoredPoint(id=1, version=0, score=1.273, payload={'city': 'Berlin'}, vector=None, shard_key=None, order_value=None), ScoredPoint(id=3, version=0, score=1.208, payload={'city': 'Moscow'}, vector=None, shard_key=None, order_value=None)]
```

Is there any solution to make my output match the official one?

name: Qdrant behind nginx reverse proxy
messages:
I am using qdrant in a docker compose network and I have a nginx reverse proxy, that sends requests to my qdrant instance. 
what I want to achieve is, to have the UI available on my HA proxy. I have seen, that there is a known issue on the github page, that shows the exact behaviour, that I am experiencing:
https://github.com/qdrant/qdrant-web-ui/issues/94

So basically whats happening, I am sending the request to 
https://myurl/qdrant/dashboard

I am using the qdrant relative path to differentiate my ressources. 
If I am removing the qdrqant in the proxy pass, what happens is, that the ui tries to find a ressource at:
https://myurl/dashboard/manifest.json

I was expecting that qdrant can handle such scenarios. Either by providing a url as environment variable or by using the forwarded headers of the proxy. I dont know if it does, but maybe there is a chance for improvement ðŸ™‚ 

Anyways, does someone have the same experience and knows how to handle this? Is there a hidden config or someone that has a good example of how to handle this in nginx?

I would be very greatful for any help.


Nginx conf: 
location /qdrant {
                rewrite ^/qdrant/(.*) /$1 break;
                proxy_pass http://qdrant-db:6333;
}

name: Disable multi-tenant index during upload?
messages:
I'm looking to configure a multi-tenant instance of qdrant with support for bulk uploads per tenant. I see the documentation for disabling the global index during bulk uploads [0], but I don't see any documentation for disabling a payload index during uploads [1]. Note that I want to disable a payload index for only one tenant during their bulk upload, while leaving other tenant indexes enabled. Is this possible, and if so how?

name: Sparse Vectors on disk and other optimization tips for large scale processing?
messages:
I'm running into trouble with resource limitations on my data processing pipeline.
Currently running a processing pipeline on computer with 64GB of RAM. Once you add in chunking / embedding processes while also hosting a qdrant image with a large amount of vectors the resource usage really starts to add up.
I've tried to set everything to 'on disk'. Despite this the RAM still seems to increase. I am then experiencing various errors where things cannot process which appear to be related to limited resource availbility.

So far I have set
- Dense vector to disk: True
- Payload to disk: True
- HNSW index to disk: True
- Sparse vectors: Can sparse vectors be stored on disk rather than RAM? It's not clear what they are by default.

Can anyone advise on the above or any other tips on how to manage data creation / upload pipelines while keeping resource usage low.
Scale of the dataset is in the order of (10M to 100M+ dense and sparse vectors). Can qdrant be set to an 'upload only' mode during processing?

Kind regards

name: Error GET Collection
messages:
When trying to use qdrant as a vector store for llama with the async client, I receive this error:
`Service internal error: 0 of 0 read operations failed`

I am using the latest docker image for qdrant.

Steps to reproduce this:

`import qdrant_client
import asyncio
import logging
import nest_asyncio
from llama_index.core import StorageContext, VectorStoreIndex
from llama_index.readers.file import CSVReader
from llama_index.vector_stores.qdrant import QdrantVectorStore
from dotenv import load_dotenv
from pathlib import Path

load_dotenv()
nest_asyncio.apply()
logging.basicConfig(level=logging.INFO)

collection = "test"

async def index():
    aclient = qdrant_client.AsyncQdrantClient(
        url='http://localhost:6333'
    )

    vector_store = QdrantVectorStore(
        aclient=aclient,
        collection_name=collection
    )

    storage_context = StorageContext.from_defaults(vector_store=vector_store)

    documents = CSVReader().load_data(Path("test.txt"))

    VectorStoreIndex(
        documents,
        storage_context=storage_context,
        use_async=True,
    )

async def main(loop):
    aclient = qdrant_client.AsyncQdrantClient(
        url="http://localhost:6333"
    )
    await aclient.delete_collection(collection)

    loop.create_task(index())
    loop.create_task(index())

    await asyncio.sleep(5)

loop = asyncio.get_event_loop()
loop.run_until_complete(main(loop))
`

This error is not deterministic, it happens most of the time.
I am thinking this has to do with concurrently trying to create a collection.

Any help will be appreciated !

name: Appending vectors to multivector points
messages:
In my database, I plan to organize a large number of "entities", each described by a set of vectors, with those entities getting new vectors over time (and new entities being added).
Is it possible to append new vectors to multivector points after they are created, or is my only option to somehow retrieve the whole entity matrix, append the new vector client-side, and then overwrite the point with this expanded matrix?
Alternatively, is there some workaround using other methods to do this? E.g., is it maybe possible to use a single-vector approach, and have each vector "point" to the entity it is describing, and then do some aggregation of similarities over each entity during search?

For reference, we're talking about ~1M entities, with ~10-100 vectors each.

Hi everyone.

Lately Iâ€™ve been looking for a way to implement keyword search with Qdrant.
Since my application supports not only English but also Japanese, I have to find a Japanese-compatible way to implement it.

I found some good Qdrant articles, and they suggested me to implement it with qdrant/bm25, qdrant/bm42 or SPLADE.
However, neither of qdrant/bm25 and bm42 seems to support Japanese.
SPLADE, on the other hand, seems to support Japanese but I donâ€™t want to use it because it heavily dependent on GPU resources.

So I was wondering if there is a way to calculate BM25 or TF-IDF score manually, maybe on the application side.

Iâ€™m kinda new to this field so please let me know if you need any additional information. Thanks in advance.

References:
- Qdrant/BM25 : https://huggingface.co/Qdrant/bm25
- Qdrant/BM42 : https://qdrant.tech/articles/bm42/

messages:
I am experiencing issues with the `/points/search/`  endpoint. The first time I use it with the following parameters, it works as expected:

  "offset" => 0,

  "with_payload" => true,
  "with_vector" => false,
  "score_threshold" => 0
]

However, when I make a second request with an `offset` of `500`
```
[
  "vector" => "...", // truncated for brevity
  "limit" => 500,
  "offset" => 500,
  "filter" => null,
  "with_payload" => true,
  "with_vector" => false,
  "score_threshold" => 0
]
```
I notice that it returns duplicate results from the first request (indices 0-500). Specifically, there are about 18 duplicated entries, which is approximately 3.6% of the results in the second request.

Alex

name: Migrate from single qdrant to cluster in k8s
messages:
Hello,
We are just starting to work with Qdrant. Our instance is running in single mode in a Docker container, so all collections were created with the parameters shard_number=1 and replication_factor=1.
We want to migrate all the data to a Qdrant cluster deployed in Kubernetes. From the documentation, I understand that when restoring a snapshot on a new node, our parameters shard_number=1 and replication_factor=1 will prevent the system from replicating data across nodes. I also found in the API documentation the Replicate Shard Operation method, which allows copying a shard from one node to another, with the new shard retaining the original shard's ID and being marked as Recovery. If I use the update_collection method to increase the replication_factor, the new shard is marked as Active, but its ID still matches the original.
Could you please advise whether replication will work in this scenario? Or is recreating the collection unavoidable?
We were able to transfer small collections through the functionality of snapshots and the api of the new cluster, but collections with a size of 5 GB cannot be imported into the new cluster via the api. 
Can you tell me what is the current migration method from single decker to the k8s cluster?
Thanks!

My idea is to initially add a sparse vector field with zero values, then, once I choose the right sparse model, I would update the existing points by upserting them with the proper sparse vectors.

Would do you think? Any better approach?

sparse_collection = "rag_sparse"

def extract_content_from_pdf(file: str) -> List:
  
    loader = PyPDFLoader(file)
    docs = loader.load()
    splitter = RecursiveCharacterTextSplitter(chunk_size=500, chunk_overlap=100)
    chunks = splitter.split_documents(docs)
    return chunks

def create_qdrant_client():

    return QdrantClient(url=qdrant_url)
def create_sparse_collection(client: QdrantClient):

messages:

I manage a Facebook page where I post recipes. I want to store the content of each post along with metrics like engagement rate, like count, share count, comment count, and post date.

My goal is to analyze trending patterns and identify any common traits between the posts that go viral. Would Qdrant help me achieve this?

Any advice or guidance would be appreciated. Thanks!

name: self hosted
messages:
I am trying to run Qdrant in a self hosted docker container. I want to enable api key and tls. 

.env :
```bash
QDRANT__SERVICE__ENABLE_TLS=1
QDRANT__TLS__CERT="/qdrant/tls/cert.pem"
QDRANT__TLS__KEY="/qdrant/tls/key.pem"
QDRANT__TLS__CA_CERT="/qdrant/tls/cacert.pem"
QDRANT__SERVICE__API_KEY="123456789"
QDRANT_URL="https://localhost:6333"
```
docker compose.yaml :
```yaml
services:
  qdrant:
    image: qdrant/qdrant:latest
    volumes:
      - ../qdrant_data:/qdrant/storage
      - ./cert.pem:/qdrant/tls/cert.pem  # Mounting the certificate file
      - ./key.pem:/qdrant/tls/key.pem  # Mounting the key file
      - ./cacert.pem:/qdrant/tls/cacert.pem # Mounting the Certificate Authority Certificate
    env_file:
      - .env
    restart: always
    ports:
      - "6333:6333"
```

name: Qdrant API/TLS issues
messages:
Hey, I am running a selfhosted qdrant server inside a docker container on my cloud server which is build from the official image and started like this: 

```docker run -p 6333:6333 -p 6334:6334 -v ${PWD}/qdrant_storage:/qdrant/storage:z -v ${PWD}/qdrant/qdrant_config.yaml:/qdrant/config/production.yaml -v ${PWD}/tls:/etc/tls:ro qdrant/qdrant```

With following config.yaml:

```
service:
  # Set an api-key.
  # If set, all requests must include a header with the api-key.
  # example header: `api-key: <API-KEY>`
  #
  # If you enable this you should also enable TLS.
  # (Either above or via an external service like nginx.)
  # Sending an api-key over an unencrypted channel is insecure.
  api_key: "612334"
  enable_tls: true

tls:
  cert: /etc/tls/qdrant-cert.pem
  key: /etc/tls/qdrant-key.pem```

Now I want to connect to qdrant from another docker container on the same cloud server where I have a llm application running. I'm connecting like this:

```cafile = '/etc/tls/rootCA.pem'
ssl_context = ssl.create_default_context(cafile=cafile)
try:
    response = urllib.request.urlopen('https://url.com:6333', context=ssl_context)
    print(response.read())
except Exception as e:
    print(f"Failed to connect: {e}")
#further code
# Qdrant connection details
url = "https://url.de"
port_qdrant = 6333

# Initialize the Qdrant client
qdrant_client = QdrantClient(
    url=url,
    port=port_qdrant,
    api_key=qdrant_local_api_key,
    https=True)```
Without TLS everything was fine. But I cannot get it running.  I was using mkcert for the creation of the certificate and key. And I even tried a suggestion from discord ```qdrantClient = QdrantClient(
        host,
        api_key,
        https=True,
        cert=(cert_file, key_file, passphrase), 
        verify=cacert_file)```
which isn't working neither.

Do you have an idea?

name: Backing up a cluster - volume inconsistencies?
messages:
hello!

We are backing up our qdrant cluster by backing up each volume individually twice per day. We haven't needed to use these backups or recover. But we all know that won't last for ever. 

So my concern revolves around inconsistencies across the backups. We cannot trigger the backups on all the volumes at the exact same moment, and the volumes are always being written to. So my sense is that a recovery will lead to some serious problems since the volumes will all have different states.

Anyone here know if this is a problem to be worried about?

Here is a comment I made on this in another thread, but the thread is likely too old to get any attention (https://discord.com/channels/907569970500743200/1149188948141297765/1279805564108406787)

name: Slow qdrant response time
messages:
I'm building an application using Qdrant that requires very fast response times. Currently, I'm using the Python Qdrant client to perform operations. My setup involves a threadpool of workers (range 0-100) making search requests using the Qdrant Python client.
Qdrant version : 1.11.3(latest docker image)
Qdrant-client(python): 1.11.1


I'm performing searches as follows:
```
start_time = time.perf_counter()
response = client.search(
    collection_name=f"{collection_name}", 
    query_vector=vector, 
    limit=n,
    search_params=models.SearchParams(
        quantization=models.QuantizationSearchParams(
            ignore=False,
            rescore=True,
            oversampling=2.0,
        )
    )
)
end_time = time.perf_counter()
```
Issue
The main problem is the high  execution time for each query when running 1000 queries sent using n workers. 

For example:  fetching 1000 results (limit=1000) with 50 concurrent workers, it takes about 300ms average per query, which is too slow for my use case.
test dataset size : 182724
vector size: 1024

Questions
1.Am I missing any optimizations in my configuration or search implementation?
2.Are there any best practices for achieving faster response times in this scenario?
3.Could switching to gRPC potentially improve performance?
Any insights or suggestions would be greatly appreciated. Thank you!

name: Different results in different environments for identical request
messages:
Hello,
I face an odd behaviour when an identical request from different machines (local and cloud) gets different results while sending request to the same Qdrant instance. I'm searching for a text which is stored in Qdrant in exact form, so I expect for exact-match.

On local machine when requests are being sent repeatedly - all responses are identical. However, when a request being sent from kubernetes app I get different responses in specific pattern.
 - First requests receives results where identical match is at the top position (similarity is around 1.01),
- Second and Third requests receives results where identical match is absent - neither in first position, neither in later but remaining results seem to be identical. Increasing results limit does not solve this problem.

This pattern of match - no match - no match affects around 2-3 % of records for some collections, for others more.

I have tried to:
- recreate collection
- reinitialize indexing by changing ef parameter after uploading points
- wait for green status before testing again
- update Qdrant version to the most recent
- update Python Qdrant client to the most recent
- use grpc and html port to see which solves problem.

Do you have any more ideas what can be a root cause of this behaviour and maybe you will give more ideas that could solve this odd issue?

name: Avoiding duplicates when using upsert
messages:
I have been kicking around with qdrant for a few days now, and I really like it.

One thing that really bugs me though, is that the `id` has to be a number or uuid. 
I ingest data from various external providers, and none of them use numbers or uuid's, they use strings such as `1706.03762` *(arXiv)* and `W4402489297` *(OpenAlex)*.
I can obviously generate the uuid's, but if I need to re-run a batch, those generated uuid's are not idempotent, and I can easily end up with duplicates.

I would rather not maintain a mapping between uuid's and actual id's during ingestion.

Has anyone solved this?

name: Cluster on suspend? NOOOO
messages:
Hello guys, today I received the email with the content:

```
Thank you very much for using Qdrant!

We realized you did not use your free tier cluster recently and will put it into a suspend mode in 2 days.

To prevent this from happening, either:

Use your cluster by sending any kind of API request to it, or
Upgrade your cluster to a paid cluster.
Paid clusters have multiple benefits, such as:

Horizontal Scaling and Replication for High Availability
Support for automatic Snapshots and Restores
Included support with response time SLAs
No automatic suspension or deletion
Guaranteed resources for increased performance
Should your cluster be suspended, your data will stay intact, and you'll have another 3 weeks to reactivate your cluster. If you do not reactivate your cluster, or upgrade to a paid cluster, it will be permanently deleted.
```

I bet, I make the API calls to it all the time, I have my clients data there but it's hard to migrate somewhere (because of the changes in the data format), it's also too small to move it to the paid one. Can you please check and prevent it from being deleted? Thanks!!

name: payload integer 0 is not scrolled
messages:
Hi, I have the following schema on my qdrant.

```
Point 86ce43bf-d995-4ca7-b686-1ff43006eb34
Payload:
chunk
hello
dhash
1738147103896277805
filename
hello
page_name
hello
point_id
0
processing_recipe
chunk_size_128_overlap_32
```

However, when trying to scroll with payload then it doesn't find the points with point_id = 0. The qdrant client starts to find in point_id = 1

what's wrong with here?

```
def get_points_collection1(client: QdrantClient, collection_name: str) -> Dict[str, Record]:
    points = {}
    offset = None
    while True:
        batch, offset = client.scroll(
            collection_name=collection_name,
            limit=1,
            offset=offset,
            with_payload=True,
            with_vectors=False,
            order_by='point_id',
        )
        for point in batch:
            point_id = point.payload.get('point_id')
            if point_id:
                points[point_id] = point  # Using point_id from payload as the key
        if offset is None:
            break
    return points
```

name: Query metadata over all collections
messages:
Hi all,
is there a built-in method to query across collections simultaneously and extract relevant metadata information (e.g. filepaths)?

My current workaround is looping over all collections like this:
````
from qdrant_client import QdrantClient

qdrant_client = QdrantClient(host='localhost', port=6333)

collections = qdrant_client.get_collections().collections

unique_file_paths = set()

for collection in collections:
    collection_name = collection.name
    # Scroll through the collection
    scroll_result = qdrant_client.scroll(
        collection_name=collection_name,
        with_payload=True
    )
    
    while scroll_result:
        points, scroll_id = scroll_result
        for point in points:
            if 'filepath' in point.payload:
                unique_file_paths.add(point.payload['filepath'])
        
        if not scroll_id:  
            break
        
        # Continue scrolling with the scroll_id
        scroll_result = qdrant_client.scroll(
            collection_name=collection_name,
            scroll=scroll_id
        )
unique_file_paths_list = list(unique_file_paths)
```

name: Suggested indexes are of different type
messages:
QDrant Notifications in Configuration issues are suggesting I create keyword payload indexes for three fields.
```Unindexed field 'src_oid' is slowing queries down in collection 'production'

Create an index on field 'src_oid' of schema "keyword" in collection 'production'. Check the documentation for more details: https://qdrant.tech/documentation/concepts/indexing/#payload-index```
These fields are meant to be of type UUID and I created UUID indexes for them. They detect valid counts for each of these fields. i.e 
```"src_oid":{
"data_type":"uuid"
"points":113005204
}```

Have I done something wrong when upserting them? 
I create index like this: 
```
qdrant_client.create_payload_index(
    collection_name=QDRANT_COLLECTION,
    field_name="src_oid",
    field_schema=models.PayloadSchemaType("uuid"),
    wait=False,
)
```
The payload values are created from bson ObjectIDs to UUID with this function: 
```
    def objectid_to_uuid(obj_id):
        padded_bytes = obj_id.binary + b"\x00" * 4
        return UUID(bytes=padded_bytes)
```
and added to the payload as is (i.e as UUID not str).

When I filter with them in searches I am using a str conversion of the UUID as the requests do not allow me to send UUIDs. Is that where I am going wrong?

I have another payload index issue where it is suggesting I create an integer payload index for a field where I only do matchAny and matchValue (no range) so I created a partial index: 
```"aff":{
"data_type":"integer"
"params":{
"type":"integer"
"lookup":true
"range":false
"is_principal":
NULL
}
"points":113005200
``` 
I get this message however: ```Unindexed field 'aff' is slowing queries down in collection 'production'

Create an index on field 'aff' of schema "integer" in collection 'production'. Check the documentation for more details: https://qdrant.tech/documentation/concepts/indexing/#payload-index```

name: RAG result matching requires narrowing of filtering?
messages:
Hello I am doing queries to Qdrant Cloud with a metafilter set to limit the date range searched.
I am searching for notes and they have tags.
What I noticed is unless I limit the tags further on top of already limiting date range, I cannot get results back that match what I am looking for.
I am already making the chunk size around 100 chars. 

Any advice on how this could be improved in Qdrant settings or something. Is that just the nature of things, that I have to limit as much as possible in metafiltering?
i.e doing this gives me nodes I want, but removing `tag` in the metafilter doesn't return me the results I want.
```
must=[
    FieldCondition(
        key="practice_date",
        range=Range(
            gte=variable_data['admission_date_unix'],
            lte=variable_data['discharge_date_unix']
        )
    ),
    FieldCondition(
        key="tag",
        match=MatchAny(any=["food", "plants"])
    ),
]
```

name: Problem with 'Must not' filter in search method
messages:
Good afternoon!

I'm working on a retrieval-augmented generation (RAG) system using Qdrant, and I'm facing an issue with redundant knowledge entries in my collection. For instance, I have multiple points that have the same content, like:

"In our platform, if you are banned, it is permanent."

These entries have different vectors but the same payload. When I perform a top K search, I retrieve one vector, store its payload, and then iterate to find other vectors with different content. Here's my current approach:

```python
Copy code
result = [first_element[0]]
seen_fish = {result[0].payload["fish"]["text_content"]}

for _ in range(1, top_k):
    next_element = client.search(
        collection_name=collection,
        query_filter=Filter(
            must=[
                FieldCondition(
                    key="bait_text_locale",
                    match=MatchValue(value=bait_text_locale),
                ),
            ],
            must_not=[
                FieldCondition(
                    key="fish",
                    match=MatchValue(value=value),
                ) for value in seen_fish
            ],
        ),
        search_params=SearchParams(hnsw_ef=512, exact=False),
        query_vector=vector,
        limit=1,
    )
    if next_element:
        new_fish = next_element[0].payload["fish"]["text_content"]
        if new_fish not in seen_fish:
            result.append(next_element[0])
            seen_fish.add(new_fish)
    else:
        break
```
The first vector works fine, but subsequent searches return empty results, even though the web UI shows entries with different payloads. I'm using the latest Qdrant version on Google Cloud.

name: full text index not exact
messages:
Hey!

We were using keyword index before with large text blocks, and without the full text index, the `MatchText` would fall back to a keyword substring match. It worked well for our particular use-case where an exact match is important.

Now, we moved to testing out the full text index in RAM, and it is fast and working quite well, except it no longer is exact. For example, when we pass `MatchText(text="Google Tag Manager")`, we get documents that have all 3 words, but not all 3 words in exact order. 

Is this by design? Are there any parameters we can tweak for forcing docs that have the full string exactly as requested in the text?

name: Upload points timed out
messages:
Hi, currently I'm testing to upload multi-vectors into my qdrant collection, i have a total of 80000 instances that need to be upload

Here is the code:
```
self.async_client = AsyncQdrantClient(
            host=self.host, port=self.port, timeout=600
        )
...
async def upsert_batch(
        self,
        collection_name: str,
        ids: List,
        embeddings: Dict,
        metadatas: Optional[Iterable[Dict[Any, Any]]],
        batch_size: int = 64,
        num_parallel_processes: int = 1,
        wait: bool = True,
    ):
        all_vectors = []
        for (dense, token,metadata, uid) in zip(embeddings['dense-vector'], embeddings['output-token-embeddings'],metadatas,ids):
            all_vectors.append(
                models.PointStruct(
                    id=uid,
                    payload=metadata,
                    vector={
                        "dense-vector": dense,
                        "output-token-embeddings":token.cpu().numpy().tolist()
                    },
                )
            )
        self.async_client.upload_points(
            collection_name=collection_name,
            points=all_vectors,
            batch_size = batch_size,
            parallel = num_parallel_processes,
            wait = wait,
        )
```

At around 70000, it always output `qdrant_client.http.exceptions.ResponseHandlingException: timed out `. All the configurations are shown as above (batch_size = 64, wait = True..etc)

I have latest qdrant-client `v1.11.0` and docker image

Could anyone provide some insight on why this occur?

name: Docker secrets with Qdrant
messages:
Hi everyone,
it seems that qdrant does not unpack docker compose secrets but only stores the secrets `/run/secrets/secret-name` and not the actual content.

I want to store my qdrant api key for simple client authentication (see here: https://qdrant.tech/documentation/guides/security/#) in a docker compose secret. Maybe this is wrong in the first place, so please feel free to also recommend a better approach. When I do this (via setting it as an environment variable), however, I cannot actually access the service with the key I set but only with the path that docker compose uses.

I follow the qdrant guide and Docker compose guide on secrets
 - https://qdrant.tech/documentation/guides/security/#
 - https://docs.docker.com/compose/use-secrets/

I share my code below:
my `docker-compose.yml`
```
services:
  # From https://qdrant.tech/documentation/guides/installation/#docker-compose
  qdrant:
    image: qdrant/qdrant:latest
    restart: always
    container_name: qdrant
    ports:
      - 6333:6333
      - 6334:6334
    expose:
      - 6333
      - 6334
      - 6335
    configs:
      - source: qdrant_config
        target: /qdrant/config/production.yaml
    volumes:
      - ./qdrant_data:/qdrant/storage
    environment:
      QDRANT__SERVICE__API_KEY: "/run/secrets/qdrant_api_key"
    secrets:
      - qdrant_api_key

configs:
  qdrant_config:
    content: |
      log_level: INFO

secrets:
  qdrant_api_key:
    file: qdrant_api_key.txt
```

Where `./qdrant_api_key.txt` is
```
12345
```

I would expect to be able to reach my service via:
`curl   -X GET http://localhost:6333/collections   --header 'api-key: 12345'`

However, instead I only reach my service via:
`curl   -X GET http://localhost:6333/collections   --header 'api-key: /run/secrets/qdrant_api_key'`

Many thanks for your help!!

on a side point, the redis helm chart handles this really well, they have the following config (among other ways of defining a key)

```
just a suggestion for the next iteration if there is currently no other way to approach this. ðŸ™‚

name: Indexing payload or using MongoDB
messages:
Dear all,

I have a question regarding indexing. Currently, we don't use and index and qdrant is obviously relatively slow; we're fully aware of this issue.
we're thinking about migrating the payload data to mongodb, since some of the queries are based on the the payload (similar to select * from publications where label = sdg3)
do you think this would help or is it already sufficient to use an index? we dont need to have super fast performance but it should be faster. Im asking this because we're not sure if we're using qdrant as it is intended. The main reason why I post this question is that we are not sure if

- We're using qdrant in an way as it it not designed for (putting to much into payload) and therefore migrate to MongoDB (only keeping the vectors in qdrant and basically querying two times, 1x qdrant for vectors and then 1x Mongodb or vice versa)
OR
- We did not fully use the potential of qdrant (missing indices)


our 2 main queries are (example for sdg 4)

1.a ) Payload based: Give me all documents that have the key "4" in predict_goals (this is basically already an abstraction since we created this payload based on the vector "goal"; we might change this if we have a working index on the vectors)
1.b ) Vector based: Give me all documents that have a value of >= 0.95 in the n-th (4th) vector in the "goal" vector.
~~1~~2. ) Payload based: Give me all documents that have the key "sdg4" in the "labels" key in payload.



Thank you very much for your opinion.


Additional Information:

- Using Qdrant in a docker container: "version":"1.10.1","commit":"4aac02315bb3ca461a29484094cf6d19025fce99"
- Using Qdrant client for python

```
{"color": "red", "occasion": ["casual", "formal"]}
```
 How can I filter the query to retrieve items where the color is **blue** or **yellow** and the occasion includes **formal** or **preppy**?

Is the following code snippet the correct way to accomplish this?
```
filter = models.Filter(
    must=[
        models.FieldCondition(
            key="color",
            match=models.MatchAny(any=["blue", "yellow"])
        ),
        models.FieldCondition(
            key="occasion",
            match=models.MatchAny(any=["formal", "preppy"])
        )
    ]
)
```

name: Point Deletion Efficiency
messages:
Hi all,
I am looking to delete points as part of updating content from documents that exist. As I understand it there are two main ways to do this and I was hoping someone could point me in the right direction as to what will be completed most efficiently:
1. Use the scroll function and filters to get all the UUIDs of the points I would like to delete and perform the deletion command on these ids or 
2. Use the delete command directly and use the filter argument within this function

The second part of my question is related to the size of deletion made. 

I've split out the points to delete based on a integer payload field that has seven options. My plan was to iterate through the seven categories of this payload field and perform my deletion and upsert sequentially (seven times) because it matches how our text scraping pipeline operates. 

However, I am wondering if it is more efficient for qdrant to have one large deletion and upsertion action rather than seven back to back.

I have created a huge collection of documents (the sqlite file is 27 GB) through private-gpt (which uses llamaindex I guess). I came to realise afterwards that it cannot be loaded to memory in local mode (that is the default setting in private-gpt for small RAG question answer setups). I am now trying to update the collection so that it can be used in on_disk mode. I tried to do it through server mode (docker image running on my laptop). However I am unable to make the server recognize the collection. It creates new folder "collections" in the storage directory when docker container is started. I copied the said collection to this folder, but it did not reconize any collection. The only way I found was to upload the collection through the web interface (http://localhost:6333/dashboard#/collections). Only .snapshot and .tar files can be uploaded (private-gpt creates a "qdrant/collection/make_this_parameterizable_per_api_call/storage.sqlite" and "qdrant/meta.json"). I created a .tar from the meta.json and the sqline and tried to upload it through web ui (took 30+ GB of memory, it started some kind of processing in my nvidia GPU [Ada2000 8 GB vram]). I killed the VM (as it would have taken many hours for this with no gurantee of results).
**Question**:
How can I make this collection useable through qdrant server? Is the upload through web-ui the only way to do it? Do I need to change the directory structure of the two files? I see that the test collections available in the web ui have a different structure (multiple folders and files), while the private-gpt (=llamaindex) created collections has only 1 file (sqlite, meta.json, and other jsons for docs and index). I would really appreciate any help if this collection can be modified somehow and made useable. Otherwise I will have to redo all 900 PDFs through a serve mode again.

name: Update and Migration of a distributed environment
messages:
Hello!

Disclaimer: We have what might not be an ideal distributed environment of qdrant. We have it like this to lower the expenses.

We are running our own distributed environment of Qdrant on AWS EC2. We only have 3 nodes: 1 in EU, 1 in Asia, and 1 in US. Each of them has its own EC2 instance, and runs through a Docker container. Qdrant version is 1.2.2.

There is only 1 shard (the one initially created in the first node, which was EU). We then replicated the shard onto the other 2 nodes. This makes it so that all the data is in sync and present in all nodes (and we need that).

1st question: how do you recommend updating the version of Qdrant? 1 node at a time, and we update every minor, correct? Basically we could start by simply building a new docker image using 1.3.0 (the version immediately after 1.2.2), deploy it in Asia, and wait for it to have an ok status, be in sync, etc. Then we would move on to US, etc. Is this the way to go? Is there a specific version of Qdrant we should aim to update to?

2nd question: We have a new ML model and we basically have to migrate all our data to the new format. For this we thought about uploading a snapshot to s3 (backup), creating a new collection through a separate server that we boot up just during the migration, recalculate all the vectors, replicate in the other two nodes, and then swap the alias to the new collection. Thoughts? Are there easier ways or something we might be missing?

Thanks!

name: Large ef_search and offset
messages:
I have a query use-case to get 200,000 nearest vectors from the database. I do realized that large offset and large `ef_search` will have significant performance impact but I wonder if there could settings that could improve it. My database has 150M vectors, 1152 dimensions, float16, 32 vCPU, 256 GB RAM. 

I'm seeing about 30-40 seconds for the query to be returned.

1. Will it be faster if I increase vCPU?
2. I experimented with `ef_search` , I had it at 500_000, 1_000_000, and 5_000_000, each request seems to returned with similar latency, but I would expect 500k to be faster than 5 mil
3. I had another database with the same set up but just 75M vectors, the same query took about half the time. I'm not an expert on HNSW, but is that expected?  I thought search performance would be more related to `ef_search` value.


Here is the config
```py
    collection_name=collection_name,
    hnsw_config=rest.HnswConfigDiff(
        on_disk=False,
        m=16,
        ef_construct=128,
    ),
    vectors_config={
        "": rest.VectorParamsDiff(
            on_disk=True
        ),
    },
    quantization_config=rest.ScalarQuantization(
        scalar=rest.ScalarQuantizationConfig(
            type=rest.ScalarType.INT8,
            quantile=0.99,
            always_ram=True,
        ),
    ),
    optimizers_config=rest.OptimizersConfigDiff(
        indexing_threshold=20000,
    ),
```

The query is 
```py
search_result = client.search(
    collection_name=collection_name, 
    query_vector=vector, 
    limit=10000,
    search_params=SearchParams(
        hnsw_ef=1_000_000,
        indexed_only=True,
        exact=False
    ),
    offset=100_000
)
```

Thanks!

name: indexed_vectors_count vs. vectors_count vs. points_count
messages:
Hi all, 

I created two collections using Qdrant client with the following implementation:
```
Qdrant.from_documents(
    doc_chunks,
    embedding_model,
    collection_name=os.getenv("QDRANT_INDEX"),
    location=os.getenv("VECTOR_BASE_URL"),
    force_recreate=True,
)
```
The first one (smaller) contains 970 `points` because `doc_chunks` contains 970 chunks, the second one (larger) contains 99885 `points` because `doc_chunks` contains 99885 chunks.

When I check the collections I get 
For 1:
- indexed_vectors_count = 0
- vectors_count = None
- points_count = 970

For  2:
- indexed_vectors_count = 98368
- vectors_count = None
- points_count = 99885

Can someone explain to me why `indexed_vectors_count` is 0 for 1? I mean every point has a multidimensional vector attached when I check a single point object.
Also I don't get why `vectors_count` = None in both cases?

According to the documentation:
- *vectors_count* - total number of vectors in a collection, useful if you have multiple vectors per point
- *indexed_vectors_count* - total number of vectors stored in the HNSW or sparse index. Qdrant does not store all the vectors in the index, but only if an index segment might be created for a given configuration.

Not sure if I got the difference ... 

Would greatly appreciate some enlightening explanation! ðŸ™ 
Thanks!

name: Confused between Lambda, EC2 and ECS for my slack RAG chatbot
messages:
Hello everyone! ðŸ‘‹

I'm currently developing a Slack bot using Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) to answer HR and company-related queries. Hereâ€™s the tech stack Iâ€™m using:

> LLM: AWS Bedrock (Mixtal 8*7b)
> Embeddings: OpenAI (text-embedding-3-small)
> Vector Store: Zilliz (serverless?) or Qdrant
> Documents Storage: AWS S3

The bot will serve multiple users in our Slack organization, allowing them to interact with it simultaneously. Additionally, it needs to store conversation history for each user, which will be used by the LLM to provide contextually relevant responses. However, Iâ€™m trying to decide between AWS Lambda, EC2, or ECS for hosting the backend, and I'm unsure which option best fits my requirements. 

I'd love to hear your experiences or recommendations for similar scenarios. What factors should I consider most, and are there best practices for these services? How do you handle storing conversation history in a scalable manner, especially when it's used by the LLM?

Thanks for your insights! ðŸ˜Š

messages:
Hi,

Receiving an error. I checked <@1016739049496662126>'s thread on a smilar topic & it did not help.

```
grpc._channel._InactiveRpcError: <_InactiveRpcError of RPC that terminated with:
    status = StatusCode.INTERNAL

>
```

This is the specific error I'm getting. My qdrant configuration is a docker-compose with the official image, and looks like this:

```
    qdrant:
      image: qdrant/qdrant:v1.9.6
      ports:
        - "127.0.0.1:6333:6333"
        - "127.0.0.1:6334:6334"
      volumes:
        - ./qdrant_data/storage:/qdrant/storage
        - ./qdrant_data/config:/qdrant/config/custom_config.yaml

Doing a little googling, WAL is the write-ahead log. Is this a simple case of no storage left on device? Because the folder seems to have like 1TB available on the mounted drive.

name: Qdrant semantic search, how to make it work?
messages:
Hello,

I implemented a small application using Qdrant and utilized the text-ada-003 model for embeddings, which allows for selecting the embedding vector size. I created a collection with 256-sized vectors and chunked the paragraphs from two pages of a book.

I watched a quick introductory video from the Qdrant team:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=AASiqmtKo54

The process I followed is similar to what was demonstrated in the video, but it doesn't seem to achieve true "semantic search." In the video, the collection of books is searched for "alien invasion," and the results only include documents with the words "alien" and "invasion" in their metadata. While this method uses cosine similarity for searching, it appears more like a keyword search rather than a search based on meaning.

I tried summarizing some paragraphs with GPT and searching using these summaries. This approach yielded some relevant chunks, but it doesn't seem to capture the deeper insights of a semantic search.

When using TensorFlow Projector, the search displays a word and its neighbors, which is more aligned with what I'm aiming for. How can I achieve similar results with Qdrant?

For example, let's take page 10 of "20,000 Leagues Under the Sea":
https://www.arvindguptatoys.com/arvindgupta/20000-leagues.pdf

Suppose we chunked the page with one vector per paragraph (let's say the five large paragraphs you can see at page 10). If I search for "Journalists talking about strange creatures," I would expect the following paragraph to have the highest confidence score semantically:

"For six months the war seesawed. With inexhaustible zest, the popular press took potshots at..."

This expectation is based on the presence of words like "press" and the talking about newspapers and nature, creatures etc. However, the current implementation seems to work well only with keywords (and is case-sensitive) rather than concepts. Like 

What am I missing to achieve a true semantic search with Qdrant?

Thank you.

name: Search time degradation in v1.9.7
messages:
Hi everyone!
I created several Qdrant databases on v1.8.X. Each one has around 300 mln vectors, 9 segments and the search time 1-2 seconds. Now I'm creating new Qdrant databases on v1.9.7 with the same config and find that 330 mln vectors take 423 segments. Moreover, search time increased from 1-2 seconds to 60+ seconds. Why? I'm using the same config. Should I forcefully decrease segments count?
I found this article https://qdrant.tech/documentation/guides/optimize/#latency-vs-throughput that give high-level understanding about segments. It describes two values of segments count: 2 and "the number of cores". So I think that 423 segments for my 32 cores is the reason of such slow search speed, isn't it? To be clear, my goal is to have min latency and I don't care about index time at all

name: Deadlock on upsert
messages:
Hi Qdrant Team, 
We are running into a deadlock on upsert and this seems to be agnostic to the qdrant version we are running. 
WARN collection::collection_manager::holders::segment_holder: Trying to read-lock all collection segments is taking a long time. This could be a deadlock and may block new updates.

Qdrant is being run locally in a docker container. I've tried upserting the same vector-set on version 1.10.0 and 1.9.4 (a version that has previously worked for us without deadlocking, but is now also deadlocking). I am finding we are hitting a deadlock at about the 200k point mark. Could this be a result of upserting too quickly and the indexing process is causing a deadlock? 

Machine specs:
CPU: Intel Xeon Gold 6314U with 24 cores
RAM: 320GB
Disk: shared network averaging ~90k IOPS

We are batch upserting vectors in batch sizes of 100 at a time. Vector specs:
Running Dense and Sparse vectors with 22 different payloads, 17 of them are indexed. The index is set prior to upserting.

name: Errors with Multivector queries
messages:
Currently, I am running qdrant locally on Docker (Version: 1.10.1, build: 4aac0231). 

I am trying to create a multimodal search engine where search results are based on image embeddings and text embeddings. I used a multivector collection:
```py
qdrant_client = QdrantClient(host="localhost", port=6333)
qdrant_client.recreate_collection(
    collection_name="titles_collection",
    vectors_config=VectorParams(size=text_embeddings.shape[1],
    distance=qdrant_models.Distance.COSINE,
    multivector_config=models.MultiVectorConfig(
            comparator=models.MultiVectorComparator.MAX_SIM
        ),),
)```

For the embeddings I used a CLIP model and stored the embeddings as such:
```py
# Preparing points to upload
points = [
    qdrant_models.PointStruct(
        id=row['id'],
        vector=[image_embedding.tolist(), text_embedding.tolist()],
        payload={'title': row['title']}
    )
    for row, image_embedding, text_embedding in zip(df.to_dict(orient='records'), image_embeddings, text_embeddings)
]

# Upload points to Qdrant
qdrant_client.upsert(
    collection_name="titles_collection",
    points=points,
)```

However, when I tried to query by following the documentation code for multivectors:
```py
title = ["Person Wearing Something"]
inputs = tokenizer.tokenize(title).to(device)
with torch.no_grad():
    query = model.encode_text(inputs).cpu().numpy()

search_results = qdrant_client.query(
    collection_name="titles_collection",
     query=[query[0],query[0]],
)```

I got the error `TypeError: QdrantFastembedMixin.query() missing 1 required positional argument: 'query_text'`

Help would be much appreciated! I'm unsure if this is even the correct approach for multimodal search in qdrant. I didn't have much luck with hybrid search either. 

Full code here:
https://colab.research.google.com/drive/1-dKPc641iD9XRZWaT32nejF7jh2I-E3Z?usp=sharing

name: Memory consumption keep increasing / not released when deleting collection
messages:
**Summary:**
We have a Qdrant cluster with collection that we delete and recreate every day. We noticed that the memory consumption of the cluster keep increasing and not released after deleting the collection.

**Details of the issue:**
We have a Qdrant cluster with collection that are setup in a blue / green manner with daily reindexing. Each day, we delete the collection that is not currently in use (flagged by an alias), recreate the collection with the new data, and switch the alias to the new collection. We noticed that the memory consumption of the cluster keep increasing and not released after deleting the collection. It reaches the point where it consumes more than the k8s memory request and I am afraid that the pod will be evicted.

If we restart the cluster, the consumption seems to be normal again. But that's not a solution.

We don't set any k8s memory limit, do you think it could improve the situation somehow?

I enclose a graph of memory consumption, blue line is used memory (`kubernetes.memory.working_set`), pink link is memory request. Memory increase each day is visible (without release). Note that our data is increasing each day but not that much.

Can you tell me if it's an expected behavior or if we are doing something wrong?

** Cluster configuration**
Limited by the max length of Discord messages, I put it in first response

messages:
I am using the free version of qdrant cloud, and haystack. 

I stored 3 documents, for this store:

    url=QDRANT_URL,

embedder = FastembedDocumentEmbedder(model="BAAI/bge-base-en-v1.5")

And then I tried the script on the web site for haystack:

# Start timing
start_time = time.time()

# Initialize document store
document_store = QdrantDocumentStore(
    url=QDRANT_URL,
    api_key=Secret.from_token(QDRANT_API_KEY),
    use_sparse_embeddings=True
)

# Time after document store initialization

# Initialize and warm up query embedder

query_embedder.warm_up()

# Time after query embedder warm-up
embedder_warmup_time = time.time()

# Initialize retriever

    document_store=document_store,  # The same document store as the one used for indexing
    top_k=3,  # Number of documents to return
)

# Initialize pipeline

search_pipeline.add_component("query_embedder", query_embedder)
search_pipeline.add_component("retriever", retriever)
search_pipeline.connect("query_embedder.embedding", "retriever.query_embedding")

# Time after pipeline setup
pipeline_setup_time = time.time()

# Print initialization times

print(f"Query embedder warm-up time: {embedder_warmup_time - doc_store_time:.2f} seconds")
print(f"Pipeline setup time: {pipeline_setup_time - embedder_warmup_time:.2f} seconds")
print(f"Total initialization time: {pipeline_setup_time - start_time:.2f} seconds")

name: Complex architecture
messages:
Hello,

I am trying to create a collection in Qdrant to store articles (both brief and detailed) and information about their authors. 
Here are the details of my problem:

**Desired Structure:**

- Each article should have `text_vector `and `image_vector `vectors, as well as payload fields like `article_title`, `article_length`, and `author_id`.
- Each author should have payload fields like `follower_count`, `article_count`, and a `text_vector `to represent the author's embedding.

**Specific Needs:**

- I do not want each article to repeat the information about `follower_count `and `article_count`. 
- I want to be able to filter articles based on both article_length and follower_count.

**Question:**

What would be the best way to set up the collection and perform such a query?

Thank you in advance for your help!

Update a key in payload with a modified version of the existing values of that key

Hello everyone, 
I am using qdrant in a langchain application, and each document stored in my qdrant vectordb has a `page_content` and a `metadata` field. The metadata field has all the information about the data in the `page_content` field ('source' and 'row_number' of the data).

On the documentation, I could find a method to update keys in the payload with a fixed string value, but what I want to do is, just remove the '/' in the existing value, which I could not make out how to do (change 4/5 to 45, etc).

name: How to Efficiently Use Qdrant Vector Search for User-Specific Queries?
messages:
Hello everyone,

Iâ€™m looking to implement vector search and could use some advice on the best approach for user-specific searches.

For instance, if Iâ€™m developing a chatbot system, I want to search for relevant information within each userâ€™s conversation history to provide context. This seems manageable with a few hundred users, but what if there are hundreds of thousands of users? Using conventional methods might consume an excessive amount of memory and resources. Separating the data into different databases or tables also seems impractical due to the sheer number of tables it would generate.

So, is there any convenient way with Qdrant? Any suggestions or insights would be greatly appreciated!

name: Multivector comparators
messages:
Hey all,

I'm super excited to start using the new multivector support for animation and audio search where I have time-series of embeddings.
With that, I'm curious if there are plans to support new comparison functions. The problem I'm anticipating I'll face with `max_sim` is I'll lose the overall maximum similarity due to the sum across vectors in the query. For example I won't know if I got similarity scores of `[0.1, 0.1, 0.1, 0.9]` or `[0.3, 0.3, 0.3, 0.3]`, the first of which is a much better match than the second.
Currently I can solve this by querying each vector in my query matrix individually, but would I be missing out on some performance optimizations behind the scenes?
I imagine an overall maximum comparator could be pretty useful in this scenario

name: Searching for many vectors
messages:
I need a help in my use case. Simply, I get a sample from user of 3 text features [A,B,C], and each data point has three vector features as well. I want the most similar data point over the three features so I encode A,B and C and match each one separately on its corresponding feature of my data points, so A is matched upon all my data points by cos similarity in my collection which is 20000 point, and same is done with B and C. Now, for each data point I merge the three matching results and have a combination of similarities with the three features of user, so I get the most similar over the three features to the user.

This solution consumes very high time as I need to make search three times, each one with limit = 20000, then merging results of similarities for all the features. It takes about 12 secs for such process and no secret it will take much more if my data is much larger. 

So my question is, Is there a way I can make match such that I get the limit of 50 most matching data points over the three features in more efficient way without need to retrieve all the data points for the three features and merge them on my own.

Please if some thing is not clear ask me to clarify it, thanks

name: BM42 article
messages:
I am trying to implement the code at the end of this article:  https://qdrant.tech/articles/bm42/, but it is not working.

I am trying to use openai for the dense embeddings, so I changed the code like so:

```
model_bm42 = SparseTextEmbedding(
        model_name="Qdrant/bm42-all-minilm-l6-v2-attentions"
    )
    model_openai = OpenAIEmbeddings(api_key=settings.openai_api_key)

    sparse_embedding = list(model_bm42.query_embed(input.question))[0]
    dense_embedding = list(model_openai.embed_query(input.question))[0]

    points = client.query_points(
        collection_name=settings.qdrant_collection_name,
        prefetch=[
            models.Prefetch(query=sparse_embedding.as_object(), using="bm42", limit=10),
            models.Prefetch(query=dense_embedding, using="openai", limit=10),

        query=models.FusionQuery(fusion=models.Fusion.RRF),  # <--- Combine the scores

name: How To Increase Replication Factor in Self-hosted Qdrant Cluster?
messages:
I am currently operating a Qdrant cluster on EKS with four shards and no set replication (effectively replication factor = 1). I aim to enhance the system's availability by increasing the replication factor and would appreciate guidance on how to achieve this.

Could you please confirm if the following approach would be appropriate?

1. Scale up the physical nodes to double the current specifications.
2. Increase the `replicaCount: 4` in `values.yml` from `4` to 8.
3. Expect that pods(shards?peers?) without data will be added to the cluster.
4. Use the new peer_id to copy existing shards to the newly added peers by `POST /collections/{collection_name}/cluster`
I'm unsure about steps 2-4, so any corrections to these assumptions or additional steps would be extremely helpful.

name: how to retrieve all points in a collection
messages:
I am trying to retrieve all points in a collection, i get error when the next page offset is not None . I trued to write a function that takes that into account but still give error " tuple object has no attribute points.

The function

# Function to scroll through all points in the collection
def retrieve_all_points(client: QdrantClient,collection_name):
    scroll_result = client.scroll(
        collection_name=collection_name,
        with_payload=True,
        with_vectors=True,
        scroll_filter=None,  )
    
    all_points = scroll_result[0]
    next_page = scroll_result[1]
    print(next_page)
    while next_page is not None:
        scroll_result = client.scroll(
            collection_name=collection_name,
            with_payload=True,
            with_vectors=True,
            scroll_filter=None, 
            offset=next_page
        )
        all_points.extend(scroll_result.points)
        next_page = scroll_result[1]
    return all_points

name: Storage deadlock when trying to recover collection
messages:
We are using 2x replication on a 30m collection with qdrant version 1.9.4 (From the logs Collection 1024_vectors) is the 30m sized collection. One of the nodes died during ingest at the 30 million mark and we've been waiting all day for it to come back online. After 30 minutes of loading we get the following message 

```
collection::collection_manager::holders::segment_holder: Trying to read-lock all collection segments is taking a long time. This could be a deadlock and may block new updates.
```
We are not adding any new data to qdrant while its trying to recover so  i'm not sure why/how it would be locked this badly. Can we restart all the nodes and free the lock?

name: Issue with Memory Usage During Qdrant Helm Version Upgrade on EKS Using Terraform
messages:
I am currently working on upgrading our Qdrant Helm deployment on EKS from version 0.9.4 to 0.10.0 using Terraform. Before the upgrade, the memory usage was as follows.
```ts
NAME                CPU(cores)   MEMORY(bytes)
qdrant-mlab-prd-0   4m           13029Mi
qdrant-mlab-prd-1   4m           13220Mi
qdrant-mlab-prd-2   7m           16831Mi
qdrant-mlab-prd-3   4m           13259Mi
```

However, while monitoring memory usage during the upgrade process, I noticed a significant increase in memory consumption, reaching 100%. In a hurry, I attempted to revert to the previous version using Terraform, but the memory usage again escalated to 100%.

```ts
NAME                CPU(cores)   MEMORY(bytes)
qdrant-mlab-prd-0   4m           13034Mi
qdrant-mlab-prd-1   5m           13223Mi
qdrant-mlab-prd-2   7m           16834Mi
qdrant-mlab-prd-3   288m         28261Mi
```

Aside from vertically scaling the cluster, are there any other solutions to this issue? Also, could this be a bug?

Thank you for your assistance.

name: Metadata Separation in Single Document Chunks
messages:
hey all! 

Im building a document search engine system using qdrant. The idea is that I am going through many documents, chunking the document content, embedding them and then inserting them into Qdrant. In am also saving the metadata for the documents as a point payload in Qdrant. 

Since I have many chunks (and consequently vectors) per document, I am currently repeatedly saving the same metadata fields into all my Qdrant points related to the same document. I can already see that as my project scales up I will be running into performance and usage issues since there will be a lot of repeated metadata. 

To avoid repeating metadata, these are the approaches that I have thought of so far:
1) Create a separate Qdrant collection to store metadata only and then reference the vectors collection with some ID

2) Store metadata externally (e.g. in MongoDB)

3) Keep doing what I assume is the naive approach of saving all metadata into all my Qdrant points (which is what im currently doing)

If anyone could provide some direction on this or has some insight please do let me know!!

Thanks <:hugging_fire:1212506142580936766>

name: Is multi vector a viable alternative to embedding averaging?
messages:
So excited about 1.10! I noticed multi vector support as documented here. https://qdrant.tech/documentation/concepts/vectors/#multivectors

We have some long documents that are bigger than our max context on the embedding models that we use. Today we are chunking, generating multiple embeddings for chunks larger than context, then averaging those vectors.

The documentation didn't call out this use case but would it be appropriate to use it for those chunks that happen to have multiple vectors instead of doing the averaging? 

The reason a chunk might be bigger than the embedding size is the chunking strategy we use is not tied to token count it's tied to the structure of the document.

name: HNSW on_disk without mmap?
messages:
Is it possible to persist HNSW index to disk wihtout mmaping it? 

Baiscally my issue is that if the HNSW index is mmaped, it will get flushed out of the OS page cache by other process' I/O if qdrant is not constantly getting queries that use it.

However, if I set on_disk=false then server startup takes more than 1h, I assume because it is rebuilding the hnsw from scratch every time.

My dataset is ~200 million vectors of 70 dimensions each, footprint on disk is 85GB.

name: Difference in benefits of creating new collection vs providing filter on payload
messages:
I'm trying to understand (maybe I missed this in the documentation), but what could be the justification for creating new collection vs adding payload which will be used to filter.
Let say I have big (over 500k records) DB of books. Those books can be either in purchase or rent category. Other than that each book has similar set of fields - genre, author, title etc.
**What would be better in such case** - creating two collections: `books_rent` and `books_sale` and populate each collection with proper subset of books, or create one combined collection `books` and use payload to store info whether book is for rent or sale?

**User will never be able to search in both subsets simultaneously.** What I mean by that is if user is performing search they are required to specify whether they are doing search for book to rent or buy.

name: support for aggregations on metadata?
messages:
Given a collection with many points, where each point has metadata that indicates where it came from, is it possible to return a list of unique values for that metadata?

Example: 3 books with 100s of points each, each point with the book ID as metadata. I can use must or should to restrict to points with specific field values on searches.

What I would like to do is be able to query the collection to return all unique values on that metadata, so I can know if some book ID is indexed or not. And to get a list of books indexed.

If I were using Elastic, I would use aggs / Aggregations. https://www.elastic.co/guide/en/elasticsearch/reference/current/search-aggregations-bucket-terms-aggregation.html

name: High Load and Slow Response Issues with Qdrant on Docker Desktop for Mac
messages:
Hello,

I am facing two significant issues with Qdrant, and I could really use some help.

After restarting the Qdrant container on Docker Desktop for Mac, there is an extremely high load for about an hour, during which it seems like the Collections are being re-indexed. During this time, Qdrant becomes unresponsive to requests, severely impacting our development process. This happens every time we restart the container.
Following the high-load period, the response time for nearest neighbor search requests becomes impractically slow, sometimes taking up to 30 seconds per request.
Our hardware setup is a MacBook Pro 2019 (Core i9 / 8-core 16 Threads), with 32GB of RAM and a 1TB SSD. We have allocated 24GB of RAM to Docker Desktop for Mac.

We are using Qdrant version 1.9.7, and we have 20 collections registered. Each collection has about 1.5 million points, and the snapshot size is approximately 35-37GB per collection.
Here is the result of running collection info:

```
next post.
```

And our ~/config/config.yaml file is as follows:

```
next post.
```
  
  Interestingly, on another MacBook Pro with M2 Max and 32GB of RAM, using the same Qdrant version and only 8 collections, the nearest neighbor search response is very fast, even after thousands of consecutive requests. (Due to storage constraints, we cannot register more collections on this machine.)

Can these two issues be resolved by adjusting any parameters in the config.yaml file?
During the high-load period, there are no outputs in the console. Is there a way to find out what Qdrant is doing during this time?
Given the large volume of collections and points, could this be a hardware limitation? (We plan to upgrade to higher-spec hardware in a few months, but we need to address the current issues in the meantime.)
Are there any other actions we can take to potentially resolve these issues?
Thank you for your assistance.

name: Multivector/Multimodal Vector Search in Individual Queries
messages:
Consider a Product Search Platform where each "product" (or point, in Qdrant terms) includes both image and text data. For example, a product may have multiple images (e.g., 5 images) and a text attribute (e.g., title).

I aim to store embeddings for all 5 images (multivector) and the title (multimodal embedding) within the same point. I also want to query these multiple vectors simultaneously. For instance, if I query using one image embedding and one text embedding at the same time, the goal would be to find the point with the closest matching image and text embeddings.

I am still working out the exact logic for this. If you have any suggestions or insights on how to implement this proof of concept (or if it's a viable approach), please share your thoughts!<:thonk:1212491184732377189>

name: Inconsistent vector
messages:
Hello,

I'm writing an qdrant upserter, and for unit test I use in-memory Qdrant client.
But I can't retreive my vectors, they're different.

**Vector inserted** : `[-0.22470705211162567, 0.3938416540622711, -0.7628212571144104, -0.6186320781707764, 0.04166025295853615]`
**Retrieved vector** : ` [-0.20756955444812775, 0.3638049364089966, -0.704643964767456,  -0.5714514851570129, 0.038482993841171265]`

Test code :
```python
ret_values_from_qdrant = self.client.scroll(
    collection_name=f"collection_corpus_en_embmodel_v2",
    limit=100,
    with_vectors=True,
)

self.assertEqual(2, len(ret_values_from_qdrant[0]))
for s in ret_values_from_qdrant[0]:
    self.assertIn(uuid.UUID(s.id), [self.slice_id0, self.slice_id1])
    e0 = self.emb0.tolist()
    e1 = self.emb1.tolist()
    self.assertIn(s.vector, [e0, e1])
    self.assertEqual(s.payload["document_id"], self.docid)
    self.assertListEqual(s.payload["document_sdg"], [1, 2])
    if s.id == self.slice_0.id:
        self.assertEqual(s.payload["slice_sdg"], 1)
    elif s.id == self.slice_1.id:
        self.assertEqual(s.payload["slice_sdg"], 2)
```
*Note : * `self.emb0` and `self.emb1` were created with numpy : `numpy.random.uniform(low=-1, high=1, size=(5,)).astype(numpy.float32)`

messages:
My aim is to build a search engine benefiting from Qdrant + AWS Neptune, where i do keyword search on AWS Neptune and vector search on Qdrant.

name: Hybrid Filtering
messages:
Hi Team,
I have a cluster with around 10 payload fields.
I will require 3 of the fields to be indexed.
Need to understand if I need to index rest 7 as well.

```
{
  "field_1": "integer", -> Indexed
  "field_2": "integer", -> Indexed
  "field_3": "integer", -> Indexed
  "field_4": "keyword", -> Not-Indexed
  "field_5": "integer", -> Not-Indexed
  "field_6": "keyword", -> Not-Indexed
  "field_7": "keyword", -> Not-Indexed
  "field_8": "integer", -> Not-Indexed
  "field_9": "bool",    -> Not-Indexed
  "field_10": "integer", -> Not-Indexed
}
```
Scenario: 
I will always run a search with filters "field_1", "field_2" and "field_3" applied. There will be additional "field_4" and "field_5" which will always be available in points which satisfy the "field_1", "field_2" and "field_3"  criteria.

Wanted to understand does Qdarnt indexed fields first and then non-indexed to optimise performance / or is the filter selection random and it can filter first based on a non-indexed field as well?

name: Scores with Discover
messages:
Hi all, 

Currently working with multiple scoring techniques that QDrant allows. Basically, the normal "recommend" with positive/negatives + best_score strategy, as well as the Discover functionality with the paired list + a target vector. I see this is in the documentation:

"Context Search: Without a target, .....the maximum score a point can achieve is 0.0, meaning many points may have a score of 0.0.

Target Search: When a target is provided......the integer part represents the rank with respect to the context, and the decimal part relates to the distance to the target. The context score for each pair is +1 if the point is closer to a positive example than to a negative example, and -1 otherwise."

When I run the search with a target, a lot of my scores are very negative (like -16) or very positive (+11).  Is it a proper interpretation that the "11" and the "-16" part then refer to the "rank with respect to the context", and the decimal after it is the distance to the target. Aka, something VERY positive in this case is probably a very relevant item?

Likewise, when I run this search without a target vector and just the paired list, my scores end up ranging from -.79 to -2.7, but I've also seen it be a mix of positive and negative. and from my understanding, the perfect score in this case is "0".  Is doing some sort of absolute value on this (aka sorting by distance to 0) the right idea?

I've created a small collection with the following details:

`{'status': 'green',
